suggestedNewContent.title: Getting Console Input in Dart
suggestedNewContent.contentOutline: Before building the game, teach dart:io library import, stdin.readLineSync() method, null safety handling with ?? operator, converting String? to int using int.tryParse(), and note that DartPad doesn't support stdin

suggestedNewContent.title: Common Game Development Pitfalls
suggestedNewContent.contentOutline: Cover: off-by-one errors in random.nextInt() (0-99 vs 1-100), handling null input, handling non-numeric input, infinite loops without exit conditions, forgetting to increment attempt counter

suggestedNewContent.title: Binary Search in Real Life
suggestedNewContent.contentOutline: Compare the guessing game to finding a word in a dictionary - you don't start at page 1, you open to the middle. Optimal strategy is always guessing the middle of the remaining range (binary search)

suggestedNewContent.title: Minimal Working Game with Real Input
suggestedNewContent.contentOutline: A 20-line complete working example using while(true), stdin.readLineSync(), int.tryParse(), and proper exit conditions that students can immediately run in their terminal

suggestedNewContent.title: The Game Loop Pattern
suggestedNewContent.contentOutline: Explain the fundamental game loop: initialize state, get input, process input, check win/lose conditions, repeat. Show how while(true) with break is the standard pattern for console games

summary: This lesson has a critical flaw: it teaches building a 'guessing game' but never teaches how to get actual user input. All examples use hardcoded arrays of simulated guesses, which defeats the purpose of an interactive game. The challenge section is broken with identical starter code and solution that contain only output text, not Dart code. The lesson needs a prerequisite section on dart:io and stdin.readLineSync() before attempting to build the game. Additionally, the lesson introduces class syntax (GameConfig) before classes have been taught in the curriculum. Despite good progressive structure (Version 1-5), the missing input handling and broken challenges make this lesson ineffective for teaching real game development.
